The Embracing Project AND THE MOBILE MEDICAL UNIT COLLABORATE TO MAKE HEALTH AND WELLNESS A TOP PRIORITY

The Nevada Health Center Mobile Medical Unit (NHCMMU) has been a staple of our collaborative community health efforts since June 2019. Every Tuesday, the van arrives at our drop-in center and transforms into a vital primary care provider for infants, children, and youth up to 21 years of age. The NHCMMU staff have become an essential part of our family by providing vital assistance to our most vulnerable populations, including sexually-exploited youth, homeless teens, runaways, undocumented youth, and young mothers. Provided services include routine lab work, physicals, general common condition care, pregnancy testing, chronic condition care, STD diagnosis, immunizations, mental health assessments, and vital education services. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, the medical bus and their incredibly dedicated staff have not missed a single day of service. We are incredibly grateful for their persistent commitment to our youth.

One-by-one, our Silver Oak Academy students went on stage, recited their passages and received the applause of an enthusiastic audience.

This past week, members of the Oak Grove Academy 4-H Club participated in Florida's "4-H Day at the Capitol" in Tallahassee. With record setting attendance making it the largest 4-H Day in Florida's history, around 1,000 youth, volunteers, family members, faculty, and staff created a sea of green wearing their 4-H shirts throughout the state's capitol. Students toured the capitol buildings (both old and new), met with their legislators, learned about the government process, and participated in a mock bill passing.

Oak Grove RAMs students also were treated to a private tour of the Tallahassee Automotive Museum and Florida State University, as well as the FSU stadium. The objective for the day was to strengthen students' citizenship skills, but they gained much more. Each student returned to campus with his own story filled with multiple "firsts" and genuine feelings of excitement about all he had experienced.

Caleb is part of a very large family who were finalists on America's Got Talent for showcasing their athletic talents and basketball spinning skills. Caleb's message of perseverance, hard work, and faith was inspirational to all in attendance. LGYS appreciates the outpouring of support and opportunities like these to partner with local organizations who, like us, are dedicated to improving the lives of youth.

Carl and Shirley were honored at Ridge View earlier this summer for their tireless generosity and sense of community.

This accreditation further demonstrates our commitment to operating programs that meet the highest standards for youth services providers nationwide and the principles embodied in the recent Family First Prevention Services Act.

A team of expert practitioners selected by CARF completed an on-site survey that measured HCA's practices against over 1,000 rigorous and internationally recognized standards for Residential Treatment. Among the many strengths recognized by the CARF surveyors, they found that "The campus fosters the development of essential skills and behaviors, enabling student athletes to have the tools and motivation to be successful when they return to their families and communities."

Uta Halee Academy has made an annual tradition of collecting diapers for the annual Diaper Drive benefitting the Lydia House and several diaper depots throughout Omaha. The Lydia House is an emergency shelter that since 1990 has provided assistance to women and families in need. Nationally, about half of all homeless women and children are fleeing domestic abuse and violence. The Lydia House offers food, shelter and safety to those who need it most, and one of the greatest needs is diapers.

This year Uta Halee Academy was able to collect over 1700 contributions. Following the collection, Uta Halee Academy's GROWL members headed to the Lydia House and in the pouring rain, helped unload 2 semi-trucks full of donations. The girls were surprised that something as simple as diapers could be in such need and that their contribution could make such a difference in the community.

Early this spring, Arkansas Juvenile Assessment and Treatment Center began a partnership with the Boys and Girls Club that resulted in the Ram Community Garden. The garden, in which students have grown several different types of peppers, tomatoes, squash, cucumbers, cantaloupe, beans, gourds, okra and pumpkins as well as a wide variety of flowers, was intended to teach the value of vegetable and herb production. Students from the construction vocational class built the raised beds where the young gardeners planted the crops - donated by the Boys and Girls Club - that they weeded and watered every day this summer.

Under the direction of paraprofessional Frances Trigeth, AJATC students have developed their ability to cooperate with one another, their responsibility, self-esteem, self-confidence and motivation while learning how to grow a garden.

The Arkansas Juvenile Assessment and Treatment Center (AJATC) recently took action through a new initiative called the "suitcase project," when it became apparent that the many of youth who arrive at the program carry their possessions in large plastic bags.

The staff-initiated "suitcase project" is made possible by reaching out to community partners, including the Arkansas Division of Youth Services, Omega Psi Phi Fraternity and several others to donate new or gently used suitcases. "There's nothing more hurtful than seeing a kid in court, standing before a judge with his or her belongings in a garbage sack," commented ROP Staff Craig Web.

The project, which has been underway since July, will greatly impact the youth our care. The suitcase, often a symbol of displacement, represents something very different for youth who arrive at AJATC: the first step toward positive permanency and a knowledge that they - as well as their possessions - have a safe place where they belong.

ROP is dedicated to improving the lives of youth not only in our direct care, but the youth that live in our communities and neighborhoods. Recently, AJATC staff took note of a "Summer Cereal Drive" hosted by a local television station, THV 11. The number of hungry children who were able to eat breakfast because of this project in prior years inspired AJATC staff to initiate a friendly, on-site competition to see who could donate the most cereal to the project. AJATC staff donated 246 boxes of cereal in just two weeks.

After the completion of the drive, AJATC received a letter from the Community Development Coordinator, which acknowledged the donations made by AJATC staff by stating: "Because of you, we were able to raise 289,217 boxes of cereal to help feed hungry children through not only the summer, but well into the year."

This experience has opened up many more opportunities for AJATC to give back to the community and set examples for our Student-Athletes that clearly show the importance of giving back.

A Safe Space is a welcoming, supportive and safe environment for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) students. To coincide with PRIDE in Northern Nevada, students at Sierra Sage Academy focused its efforts on creating "A Safe Space" by becoming effective allies to the LGBT students in their school and community by hosting a series of workshops.

Sierra Sage Academy students facilitated Ally 101 workshops that focused on how to become a positive support for their LGBT peers.

The Ally 101 workshops are based in research that has demonstrated that LGBT students with more support feel safer at school, skip fewer classes and earn higher grades. SSA students are making a positive difference for their LGBT peers, so they know that they are supported by their peers and the adults in their lives.

Rite of Passage and The Centers for Youth and Families, Inc. have partnered to open Destiny House, a 20-bed group home in Little Rock, Arkansas. Both agencies bring extensive experience in serving youth, families and communities, and share a commitment to improving lives.

Rite of Passage programs prepare students in its programs for the 21st Century Workplace. Our organization does this by offering accredited education, relevant career-technical education and opportunities to explore future endeavors - whether those include employment or post-secondary education - through the relationships our programs form with community partners.

Five local community colleges and universities came to campus to offer our students a "glimpse" of what their campus has to offer. Every UHA student learned about the degree and certification programs each institution offers, as well as the basic requirements for each.

As students wandered from table to table, they were fully engaged, and asked lots of questions to the representatives from each college or university. The students left the College Fair excited about the possibilities that wait for them after high school.

Quality, accredited and meaningful education rests at the heart of Rite of Passage programs; for 35-years, our organization has provided at-risk youth populations with opportunities for bright futures with our focus on academic excellence. This tradition continues at Sierra Ridge Academy where students recover credits, increase competencies in core subject matter and, through an accredited-WASC education, enable youth to meet one essential milestone: receiving a high school diploma.

Sierra Ridge Academy recently celebrated the graduation of 12 high school students. With over 100 supports in the audience, the ceremony commenced with a speech by the Valedictorian, SRA RAM Anthony G.

The ceremony concluded with a Flower Ceremony, another longtime Rite of Passage tradition that enables youth to acknowledge a teacher or staff who helped them-and a video that highlighted the success of our graduates and SRA campus life.

Rite of Passage programs form community partnerships to enrich and diversify the kind of experiences students have while in our programs. DePaul Academy's newest community partner, the Potawatomi Zoo in South Bend, Indiana, has graciously provided students with opportunities to learn about is operations through beautification projects and feeding some of the animals.

The Zoo, which is the oldest in Indiana, features nearly 500 animals and will offer DPA students opportunities to help with maintaining the zoo grounds, learning about the animals, painting and cleaning activities.

Recently, students helped zoo staff in filling planters and pots with ornamental flowers. In return, students were treated to tour of the zoo grounds in which they were able to feed animals on the farm. One Student-Athlete remarked that, "...when I was feeding the llama, I was scared at first, but then I had fun. I enjoyed the tour, and I can't wait to do future projects with the zoo."

Rite of Passage programs have a 30+ year history of providing students with relevant technical career education. This tradition continues at JoAnn Bridges Academy where student-athletes have the opportunity to particpate in a Certified Nursing Assistant Program.

Through the CNA certification program, eligible students are enrolled in a Medical Skills course taught by a Licensed Registered Nurse. Upon completion of the course, students earn a full elective course credit. When students reaches the age of 18, they become eligible to challenge the Florida Board of Nursing's Certified Nursing Assistant exam to become licensed.

Recently, four JBA students successfully completed the first cycle the semester-long class. These students obtained both the knowledge and the practical skills required to earn their certification. Working as a CNA will allow them to utilize all the skills learned throughout the program, and return to their communities equipped to participate as productive citizens.

Rite of Passage is pleased to announce the promotion of Tachicka Malvin as the Program Manager at Destiny House, a 20-bed residential program opening in Little Rock, Arkansas.

Malvin was promoted to this key leadership position following thirteen years' experience serving Arkansas youth at the Arkansas Juvenile Assessment and Treatment Center (AJATC) and the Boys & Girls Club of Saline County.

Most recently, Malvin served as the Admissions & Transitions Coordinator at AJATC where she was named Employee of the Year in 2017 for her outstanding performance. She holds a Bachelors degree from the University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff and was tapped by Delta Community Based Services as a substance abuse presenter. Additionally, Malvin is a member of the 2018 Rite of Passage Leadership Education Apprenticeship Program (LEAP), a year-long management training program to develop future leaders.

When she's not working, Ms. Malvin enjoys cooking and spending time with her family.

Rite of Passage programs instill the values of responsible citizenry and stewardship into our student-athletes through programming that focuses on the importance of leadership and of giving back. One Sierra Sage Academy student, Zoe, developed a unique-yet important-way to give back to her community.

According to the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), every person should have basic supplies on hand in order to survive for at least three days if an emergency should occur. When Zoe checked with local schools, she found a way to help make the students of Yerington High School safer by providing them with classroom emergency kits in the event of a natural disaster.

For her Leadership Community Service project, Zoe gave presentations asking for community donations for items needed to assemble 29 emergency kits for each class room. The community responded, and Zoe diligently created and delivered the kits. Because of Zoe's project, the classrooms at Yerington High School now have kits equipped with water, food, first aid and hygiene supplies.

As a Rite of Passage program, DePaul Academy encourages its students to participate in sanctioned, community events. This provides opportunities for pro-social interactions and grants our students glimpses of the resources in the community to which they will transition. One event that is quickly becoming a DePaul Academy tradition is the River Park Annual Parade.

DePaul students walked and participated in the parade; they waved to spectators and even watched other floats. Incredibly, this was the first time for most of our students to participate in a parade; and it was an experience that several remarked "was cool."

River Park is located on the east side of South Bend, near the future site of Woodford Home that will serve as a transitional home for DePaul students.
